message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Observer-Based Sliding Mode Control for Networked Fuzzy Singularly Perturbed Systems Under Weighted Try-Once-Discard Protocol
Paper Abstract: In this article, the sliding mode control issue is investigated for a class of discrete-time Takagi–Sugeno fuzzy networked singularly perturbed systems via an observer-based technique. Moreover, to process the measurement output and schedule the transmission sequence for relieving the communication burden, a logarithmic quantizer and a weighted try-once-discard protocol are synthesized, which can further improve the network bandwidth utilization in networked control systems. Based on the fuzzy observer states, a novel fuzzy sliding surface is established by considering the singularly perturbed parameter properly, and we endeavor to synthesize a sliding mode control law such that the reachability of the prescribed sliding surface could be guaranteed. In addition, by virtue of the convex optimization theory and Lyapunov approach, sufficient conditions are developed to guarantee the asymptotic stability of the sliding mode dynamics as well as the error system with an expected <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$H_{\infty }$</tex-math></inline-formula> performance. Finally, a verification example is presented to illustrate the feasibility and effectivity of the proposed method.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's information about Takagi-Sugeno Fuzzy Logic Control:

## Overview

The Takagi-Sugeno-Kang (TSK) model is a precise fuzzy modeling approach focused on accuracy, in contrast to the more interpretable Mamdani model.

## Key Advantages

The main advantage of using TSK over Mamdani is that it is computationally efficient and works well within other algorithms, such as PID control and with optimization algorithms. Additionally, it can guarantee the continuity of the output surface.

However, Mamdani is more intuitive and easier to work with by people.

## Applications

TSK is usually used within other complex methods, such as in adaptive neuro fuzzy inference systems. In fact, an adaptive neuro-fuzzy inference system (ANFIS) is a kind of artificial neural network that is based on Takagi–Sugeno fuzzy inference system.

The TSK model is particularly suited for applications that require high accuracy and computational efficiency in fuzzy logic control systems, making it a popular choice in modern fuzzy control applications where integration with optimization algorithms and other advanced techniques is necessary.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Sliding Mode Control:

## Definition and Overview

Sliding mode control (SMC) is a nonlinear control method that alters the dynamics of a nonlinear system by applying a discontinuous control signal that forces the system to "slide" along a cross-section of the system's normal behavior.(no content)Sliding mode control is a variable structure control method.

## How It Works

Sliding mode control uses practically infinite gain to force the trajectories of a dynamic system to slide along the restricted sliding mode subspace.(no content)The control law can switch from one continuous structure to another based on the current position in the state space.

## Key Advantages

The main strength of sliding mode control is its robustness. Because the control can be as simple as a switching between two states (e.g., "on"/"off"), it need not be precise and will not be sensitive to parameter variations. Additionally, because the control law is not a continuous function, the sliding mode can be reached in finite time.

## Challenges

Real implementations of sliding mode control approximate theoretical behavior with a high-frequency switching control signal that causes the system to "chatter" in a tight neighborhood of the sliding surface.(no content)Chattering can be reduced through the use of deadbands or boundary layers around the sliding surface.

## Applications

Sliding mode control has many applications in robotics, and has been used for tracking control of unmanned surface vessels with high degree of success.

Matkowsky - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bernard_J._Matkowsky"},{"title":"Perturbation theory (quantum mechanics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perturbation_theory_(quantum_mechanics)"},{"title":"Category:Perturbation theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Perturbation_theory"},{"title":"Perturbation problem beyond all orders - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perturbation_problem_beyond_all_orders"},{"title":"Singular spectrum analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singular_spectrum_analysis"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of singular perturbation:

## Definition

A singular perturbation problem is a problem containing a small parameter that cannot be approximated by setting the parameter value to zero. This contrasts with regular perturbation problems where the solution can be approximated by simply setting the small parameter to zero.

## Key Characteristics

A singular perturbation generally occurs when a problem's small parameter multiplies its highest operator, and naively taking the parameter to be zero changes the very nature of the problem.(no content)In the case of differential equations, boundary conditions cannot be satisfied; in algebraic equations, the possible number of solutions is decreased.

## Methods and Techniques

Basic methods for addressing singular perturbation problems include the method of matched asymptotic expansions and WKB approximation for spatial problems, and in time, the Poincaré–Lindstedt method, the method of multiple scales and periodic averaging.

## Applications

An electrically driven robot manipulator can have slower mechanical dynamics and faster electrical dynamics, exhibiting two time scales. In such cases, the system can be divided into two subsystems corresponding to faster and slower dynamics, and through singular perturbation techniques, these subsystems can be made independent of each other, thereby simplifying the control problem.(no content)Singular perturbation theory is a rich and ongoing area of exploration for mathematicians, physicists, and other researchers.

Web search results for query: "Quantization Signal Processing"

Links: [{"title":"Quantization (signal processing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantization_(signal_processing)"},{"title":"Talk:Quantization (signal processing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Quantization_(signal_processing)"},{"title":"Digital signal processing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_signal_processing"},{"title":"Digital signal (signal processing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_signal_(signal_processing)"},{"title":"Signal processing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signal_Processing"},{"title":"Signal-to-noise ratio - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signal_to_noise_ratio_(image_processing)"},{"title":"Signal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signal_(signal_processing)"},{"title":"Signal-to-quantization-noise ratio - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signal-to-quantization-noise_ratio"}]

## Quantization in Signal Processing

Quantization is the process of mapping input values from a large set (often a continuous set) to output values in a (countable) smaller set, often with a finite number of elements.

### Basic Concept

An analog-to-digital converter (ADC) can be modeled as two processes: sampling and quantization. Sampling converts a time-varying voltage signal into a discrete-time signal, a sequence of real numbers. Quantization replaces each real number with an approximation from a finite set of discrete values.(no content)Rounding and truncation are typical examples of quantization processes.

### Quantization Levels and Representation

Most commonly, these discrete values are represented as fixed-point words. Common word lengths are 8-bit (256 levels), 16-bit (65,536 levels) and 24-bit (16.8 million levels).

### Quantization Error and Noise

Quantizing a sequence of numbers produces a sequence of quantization errors which is sometimes modeled as an additive random signal called quantization noise because of its stochastic behavior.(no content)The more levels a quantizer uses, the lower is its quantization noise power.(no content)In order to make the quantization error independent of the input signal, the signal is dithered by adding noise to the signal. This slightly reduces signal-to-noise ratio, but can completely eliminate the distortion.

### Quality Measurement

Signal-to-quantization-noise ratio (SQNR or SNqR) is widely used quality measure in analysing digitizing schemes such as pulse-code modulation (PCM). The SQNR reflects the relationship between the maximum nominal signal strength and the quantization error introduced in the analog-to-digital conversion.

Links: [{"title":"Quantization (signal processing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantization_(signal_processing)"},{"title":"Talk:Quantization (signal processing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Quantization_(signal_processing)"},{"title":"Digital signal processing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_signal_processing"},{"title":"Digital signal (signal processing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_signal_(signal_processing)"},{"title":"Signal processing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signal_Processing"},{"title":"Signal-to-noise ratio - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signal_to_noise_ratio_(image_processing)"},{"title":"Signal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signal_(signal_processing)"},{"title":"Signal-to-quantization-noise ratio - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signal-to-quantization-noise_ratio"}]

## Quantization in Signal Processing

Quantization is the process of mapping input values from a large set (often a continuous set) to output values in a (countable) smaller set, often with a finite number of elements.

### Basic Concept

An analog-to-digital converter (ADC) can be modeled as two processes: sampling and quantization. Sampling converts a time-varying voltage signal into a discrete-time signal, a sequence of real numbers. Quantization replaces each real number with an approximation from a finite set of discrete values.(no content)Rounding and truncation are typical examples of quantization processes.

### Quantization Levels and Representation

Most commonly, these discrete values are represented as fixed-point words. Common word lengths are 8-bit (256 levels), 16-bit (65,536 levels) and 24-bit (16.8 million levels).

### Quantization Error and Noise

Quantizing a sequence of numbers produces a sequence of quantization errors which is sometimes modeled as an additive random signal called quantization noise because of its stochastic behavior.(no content)The more levels a quantizer uses, the lower is its quantization noise power.(no content)In order to make the quantization error independent of the input signal, the signal is dithered by adding noise to the signal. This slightly reduces signal-to-noise ratio, but can completely eliminate the distortion.

### Quality Measurement

Signal-to-quantization-noise ratio (SQNR or SNqR) is widely used quality measure in analysing digitizing schemes such as pulse-code modulation (PCM). The SQNR reflects the relationship between the maximum nominal signal strength and the quantization error introduced in the analog-to-digital conversion.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Networked Control Systems:

## Definition and Overview

A networked control system (NCS) is a control system wherein the control loops are closed through a communication network.(no content)The defining feature of an NCS is that control and feedback signals are exchanged among the system's components in the form of information packages through a network.

## Key Challenges

The insertion of the communication network in the feedback control loop makes the analysis and design of an NCS complex, since it imposes additional time delays in control loops or possibility of packages loss.

Several important research topics have emerged related to NCS, including "new control strategies, kinematics of the actuators in the systems, reliability and security of communications, bandwidth allocation, development of data communication protocols, corresponding fault detection and fault tolerant control strategies, real-time information collection and efficient processing of sensors data."

## Design Approaches

Many researchers provided solutions using concepts from several control areas such as robust control, optimal stochastic control, model predictive control, fuzzy logic etc.

## Network Types

Networked control systems can operate over various types of networks, including wireless networks, e.g. Bluetooth, Zigbee, and Z-Wave.(no content)The term wireless networked control system (WNCS) is often used in this connection.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Lyapunov equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_equation"},{"title":"Lyapunov optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_optimization"},{"title":"Lyapunov theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_theorem"},{"title":"Aleksandr Lyapunov - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Lyapunov"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"LaSalle's invariance principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LaSalle's_invariance_principle"},{"title":"Orbital stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orbital_stability"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Lyapunov Stability:

## Overview

Near a point of equilibrium which is Lyapunov stable, the system remains stable under small disturbances. More formally, Lyapunov stability means that if the system starts in a state x≠0 in some domain D, then the state will remain in D for all time.

## History

Lyapunov stability is named after Aleksandr Mikhailovich Lyapunov, a Russian mathematician who defended the thesis The General Problem of Stability of Motion at Kharkov University in 1892.(no content)Lyapunov was a pioneer in developing a global approach to the analysis of the stability of nonlinear dynamical systems by comparison with the widely spread local method of linearizing them about points of equilibrium.

## Types of Stability

Asymptotic stability means that solutions that start close enough not only remain close enough but also eventually converge to the equilibrium.

## Methods and Applications

Lyapunov functions, named after Aleksandr Lyapunov, are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ordinary differential equation.(no content)Lyapunov functions (also called Lyapunov's second method for stability) are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.(no content)The concept of the Lyapunov exponent (related to Lyapunov's First Method of discussing stability) has received wide interest in connection with chaos theory.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of discrete-time systems:

## Definition

In theoretical computer science, a discrete system is a system with a countable number of states.(no content)Discrete systems may be contrasted with continuous systems, which may also be called analog systems.

## Signals and Time

A discrete signal or discrete-time signal is a time series consisting of a sequence of quantities. Unlike a continuous-time signal, a discrete-time signal is not a function of a continuous argument; however, it may have been obtained by sampling from a continuous-time signal.(no content)A discrete-time signal has a countable domain, like the natural numbers.

## Origins of Discrete-Time Signals

Discrete-time signals may have several origins, but can usually be classified into one of two groups: By acquiring values of an analog signal at constant or variable rate. This process is called sampling. By observing an inherently discrete-time process, such as the weekly peak value of a particular economic indicator.

## Mathematical Characteristics

Because discrete systems have a countable number of states, they may be described in precise mathematical models.(no content)A discrete-time linear time-invariant (or, more generally, "shift-invariant") system is defined as one operating in discrete time, where convolution uses a discrete summation rather than an integral.

## Applications

Discrete-time signals, used in digital signal processing, can be obtained by sampling and quantization of continuous signals.

A discrete signal or discrete-time signal is a time series consisting of a sequence of quantities. Unlike a continuous-time signal, a discrete-time signal is not a function of a continuous argument; however, it may have been obtained by sampling from a continuous-time signal.(no content)A discrete-time signal has a countable domain, like the natural numbers.

## Origins of Discrete-Time Signals

Discrete-time signals may have several origins, but can usually be classified into one of two groups: By acquiring values of an analog signal at constant or variable rate. This process is called sampling. By observing an inherently discrete-time process, such as the weekly peak value of a particular economic indicator.

## Mathematical Characteristics

Because discrete systems have a countable number of states, they may be described in precise mathematical models.(no content)A discrete-time linear time-invariant (or, more generally, "shift-invariant") system is defined as one operating in discrete time, where convolution uses a discrete summation rather than an integral.

## Applications

Discrete-time signals, used in digital signal processing, can be obtained by sampling and quantization of continuous signals.

Web search results for query: "H-infinity control theory"

Links: [{"title":"H-infinity methods in control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H-infinity_methods_in_control_theory"},{"title":"H-infinity loop-shaping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H-infinity_loop-shaping"},{"title":"Robust control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robust_control"},{"title":"Talk:H-infinity methods in control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:H%E2%88%9E"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Hamiltonian (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamiltonian_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Algebraic Riccati equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algebraic_Riccati_equation"},{"title":"Pontryagin's maximum principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pontryagin's_maximum_principle"},{"title":"Controllability Gramian - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Controllability_Gramian"},{"title":"Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman_equation"}]

Based on the web search results, here's information about H-infinity control theory:

## Overview

H-infinity methods are used in control theory to synthesize controllers to achieve stabilization with guaranteed performance.(no content)A control designer expresses the control problem as a mathematical optimization problem and then finds the controller that solves this optimization.

## Advantages and Disadvantages

H-infinity techniques have the advantage over classical control techniques in that they are readily applicable to problems involving multivariate systems with cross-coupling between channels; disadvantages include the level of mathematical understanding needed to apply them successfully and the need for a reasonably good model of the system to be controlled.

## Mathematical Foundation

The phrase H-infinity control comes from the Hardy space of matrix-valued functions that are analytic and bounded in the open right-half of the complex plane; the H-infinity norm is the supremum singular value of the matrix over that space.(no content)For matrix-valued functions, the norm can be interpreted as a maximum gain in any direction and at any frequency; for single-input single-output systems, this is effectively the maximum magnitude of the frequency response.

## Historical Development

These methods were introduced into control theory in the late 1970s-early 1980s by George Zames (sensitivity minimization), J. William Helton (broadband matching), and Allen Tannenbaum (gain margin optimization).

## Related Approaches

H-infinity loop-shaping is a design methodology in modern control theory that combines the traditional intuition of classical control methods with H-infinity optimization techniques to achieve controllers whose stability and performance properties hold despite bounded differences between the nominal plant and the true plant.

Web search results for query: "Observer-based Control"

Links: [{"title":"State observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_observer"},{"title":"Observability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observability"},{"title":"Observer pattern - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observer_design_pattern"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observer"},{"title":"Controllability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Controllability"},{"title":"Talk:State observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:State_observer"},{"title":"Inversion of control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inversion_of_control"},{"title":"Forward observers in the U.S. military - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forward_observers_in_the_U.S._military"},{"title":"United Nations General Assembly observers - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_observers"}]

Based on the web search results, here's information about Observer-based Control:

## Overview

In control theory, a state observer, state estimator, or Luenberger observer is a system that provides an estimate of the internal state of a given real system, from measurements of the input and output of the real system.(no content)It is typically computer-implemented, and provides the basis of many practical applications.

## Why It's Needed

In most practical cases, the physical state of the system cannot be determined by direct observation. Instead, indirect effects of the internal state are observed by way of the system outputs.(no content)A simple example is that of vehicles in a tunnel: the rates and velocities at which vehicles enter and leave the tunnel can be observed directly, but the exact state inside the tunnel can only be estimated.

## Application in Control

Knowing the system state is necessary to solve many control theory problems; for example, stabilizing a system using state feedback.(no content)All system states are not in general measured and so observers must be included and incorporated in pole placement design.

## Types of Observers

Sliding mode control can be used to design an observer that brings one estimated state's error to zero in finite time even in the presence of measurement error; the other states have error that behaves similarly to the error in a Luenberger observer after peaking has subsided. Sliding mode observers also have attractive noise resilience properties that are similar to a Kalman filter.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Instead, indirect effects of the internal state are observed by way of the system outputs.(no content)A simple example is that of vehicles in a tunnel: the rates and velocities at which vehicles enter and leave the tunnel can be observed directly, but the exact state inside the tunnel can only be estimated.

## Application in Control

Knowing the system state is necessary to solve many control theory problems; for example, stabilizing a system using state feedback.(no content)All system states are not in general measured and so observers must be included and incorporated in pole placement design.

## Types of Observers

Sliding mode control can be used to design an observer that brings one estimated state's error to zero in finite time even in the presence of measurement error; the other states have error that behaves similarly to the error in a Luenberger observer after peaking has subsided. Sliding mode observers also have attractive noise resilience properties that are similar to a Kalman filter.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about robust control:

## Definition and Overview

Robust control refers to theory of feedback regulation that began taking shape in the late 1970's and onwards, where modeling uncertainty is explicitly acknowledged, modeled, and taken into account in control design.(no content)The ability of a feedback control system to maintain stability and performance under uncertainty is referred to as robustness.

## Key Concepts

Tolerance to modeling uncertainty is an essential part of any feedback control scheme, that is, the ability to maintain a satisfactory level of performance when the system dynamics deviate from the nominal value used in the design.(no content)Modeling uncertainty is typically quantified, as is performance, and together are sought to be optimized by casting control design as a suitable optimization problem.

## Types of Uncertainty

Parametric uncertainty refers to the case where modeling parameters or external disturbances in feedback regulation are expected to be found within some (typically compact) set of a finite dimensional space, and robust control aims to achieve robust performance and stability in the presence of such bounded modeling errors.(no content)Non-parametric uncertainty refers to the case where the magnitude of expected modeling errors and disturbances is quantified via metrics on function spaces where these reside (infinite dimensional).

## Historical Development

The term robust control was not used until the 1980's when modern methods started being developed to optimize for parametric and non-parametric modeling uncertainty.(no content)The term robust control became almost synonymous with the term H-infinity control, since it was the techniques in the development of the latter that gave the early impetus for the new methods.

## Comparison with Adaptive Control

Robust control guarantees that if the changes are within given bounds the control law need not be changed, while adaptive control is concerned with control law changing itself.
